page.title: 15Farming in the Glanaman area
page.content: Approximately two thirds of the area around Glanaman is given over to agriculture. Much of the land is not of the best quality, therefore sheep farming is predominant, farmers supplementing their own pasture by making use of grazing rights on the nearby Black and Betws Mountains. Crops such as hay may be grown to provide winter feed for the animals. Most farms were established before the development of Glanaman as a mining community, and the underlying coal measures have meant that tracts of farmland have been mined and re-planted in the recent past. Consequently, there is the constant threat that farmers may have sections of their property compulsorarily purchased by the National Coal Board for the development of opencast mining.
